issue.title: Add go function invocation runtime as a package

labels.name: needs-rebase
labels.description: Indicates a PR cannot be merged because it has merge conflicts with HEAD.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: size/XXL
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: do-not-merge/hold
labels.description: Indicates that a PR should not merge because someone has issued a /hold command.

issue.body:
# Changes

This change takes the Golang function invocation framework from [boson-project/packs](https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/e8e1b3b08ac5599c71e999a52a0ff4c0432baa29/buildpacks/go/faas) and adds that code as a package to `func` itself. We should consider instead if it makes more sense to move this to https://github.com/knative/pkg.

- 🎁 Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- 🎁 Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package

## Motivation

Doing this will remove some of the "magic" from how a Golang function works. It also solves a number of problems.

- Eliminates the need to maintain a function-specific buildpack in https://github.com/boson-project/packs
- Allows us to default to the paketo golang buildpack alone, and for users to use any go-capable buildpack they want
- Enables on-cluster builds for Go functions, which is currently prevented by limitations in the Tekton task related to specifying additional buildpacks
- Enables s2i builds for Go functions, as the framework is now simply a library dependency instead of being applied in the buildpack
- Enables the function developer to run the function locally without requiring a container image and docker daemon
- Makes the function invocation mechanism for Go functions more transparent/open for greater potential community input

## Areas of concern

- Requires a minimal `main()` to be included in the Go function templates (this PR adds `faas/main.go`)
- Requires either `go.sum` in the Go function templates, or the user must generate it before an initial `func build` (this PR adds `go.sum`)
- Adds gorilla/mux as a dependency to `func` (unless the package is moved to `knative.dev/pkg/runtime`)

## TODO
- [x] Remove check preventing on-cluster builds for golang
- [ ] Update go.mod `replace` directives if/when this PR lands (is there a better way to do this?)
- [ ] Update template README.md docs to provide instructions on how to run the function locally

/kind enhancement

Fixes: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/809
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/984
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/pull/1445

## Release notes
```release-notes
- Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package
```

issue.title: Determine the process of how/what envoy configurations we support

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
There are some requests to add a new Envoy configuration on Kourier recently.
But we don't have the process of how/what envoy configurations we support and so the new configurations could mess up the Kourier code and cause confusion why this is supported but why this is not.
We should determine the process.

### How to support the configuration

In many cases, the configuration could be supported by introducing a new annotation.
However, the annotation solution is a double-edged sword, which means easy to add but mess up the configuration. (we will eventually support a ton of the annotations).
Is there any better way?

### What envoy feature/configuration support

There are so many envoy configurations. We probably need to select some of them with a criteria such as many users requested, critical configurations and so on.

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: area/API
labels.description: API objects and controllers

labels.name: kind/spec
labels.description: Discussion of how a feature should be exposed to customers.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
/area API
/area monitoring
/kind spec

## Ask your question here:

Hey folks! In my setup I'm using Argo Rollouts to rollout different applications. I combine it with ArgoCD as well to take full advantage of GitOps. I've been playing around with the Canary, Blue/Green deployment of the `Service` CRD of Knative Serving but I was wondering if there was a way to leverage Argo Rollouts instead of the default rollout mechanism. What I am trying to achieve is the automatic rollback of a `Revision` based on rules that I can set per individual `Service`. 
Maybe this could be a `feature-request` rather than a question, however, before moving on I'd like to know if there are already mechanisms to take advantage of Argo Rollouts.

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: Paul S. Schweigert <paul@paulschweigert.com>

Github recently made the `ubuntu-latest` runner label refer to Ubuntu 22.04 (before it had been 20.04). 22.04 uses cgroups v2 by default, whereas 20.04 was still using cgroups v1.

It seems that our cgroups conformance tests were written for cgroups v1, as they fail when using cgroups v2 (tested on both Ubuntu 22.04 and Fedora 36).

As a short-term solution, this patch will keep running the e2e tests on Ubuntu 20.04, until we have a chance to rewrite the conformance tests to work with cgroups v2.

issue.title: Allow more control on configuration of virtual services being created by net-istio controller.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
### Context:
We are running kserve on top of knative-serving. For every kserve InferenceService (aka ISVC), 3 virtual services are being created by net-istio controller:
1. one created with the same name as ISVC => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
2. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-ingress => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
3. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-mesh => bound to `mesh` gateway

Now, at our org, we have a central team that manages service mesh and they have a set of rules (implemented via validation webhooks) in place for every istio resource like VS, GW, Service Entry etc.
One such rule is, for every virtual service that is bound to a mesh gateway, it is mandatory to have `exportTo:"."` in that virtual service's spec.

### Ask:
It should be possible to influence the configurations of virtual services created by net-istio controller as every organization can have a central service mesh team having their own set of rules enforced.

issue.title: What does the concurrency really mean?

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue with Knative, send an email to knative-security@googlegroups.com. -->

In what area(s)?
> /area metrics

The question is about the metrics system.
Let's assume that:
- there is only one autoscaler and an activator which regularly (1s) reports its metrics to the autoscaler
- the response time is infinite, which means the request will never end (timeout config is also infinite)

In my opinion, the concurrency is just the "current" request numbers which the activator (and the pods behind it) is dealing with. That means, if there is one request comes at the first second, and another comes at the second second... and so on, then the concurrency is 1 at the first second and 2 at the second second... Is that right?

However in knative, the activator will reset its data after it reports its metrics periodically, which means it doesn't know the request it received at the last report frame, so it will report 1 AverageConcurrency at the 1st second, and another 1 AverageConcurrency at the 2nd... and so on. Thus the autoscaler will think the concurrency is always equal to one by the whole StableWindow (60s) . But actually all the requests are being processed by the backend, **so the question is **,  what is the right concurrency after the whole StableWindow, 60 or 1?

Thanks a lot.

issue.title: Knative + Kourier -  use with AWS App Mesh

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Well-understood/specified features, ready for coding.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
Hi there.

Problem statement: Use knative + Kourier with AWS App Mesh sidecar injection

Detail:

We know its possible to use Istio's Service Mesh (sidecar injection) with Knative.
I have also seen resources to do the same with Linkerd.

It would be great if we can get the same for AWS App Mesh.

Ive tried injecting the envoy sidecar with Knative + AppMesh. The sidecar injects and the pod starts up fine with 3/3 containers. 
Traffic/routing doesnt work as soon as the envoy sidecar is added.
I see that as soon as the envoy container is added, the k8s Service - External Name is not being created:

(you will see two services below instead of the 3 knative usually creates, also please note the "Unkowns" and "RevisionMissing")


```
NAME                                TYPE        CLUSTER-IP       EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)                                      AGE
service/my-service-01           ClusterIP   172.20.198.104   <none>        80/TCP                                       11m
service/my-service-01-private   ClusterIP   172.20.218.251   <none>        80/TCP,9090/TCP,9091/TCP,8022/TCP,8012/TCP   11m

NAME                                           READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
deployment.apps/my-service-01-deployment   0/1     1            0           11m

NAME                                                      DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/my-service-01-deployment-59d9bc7778   1         1         0       11m

NAME                                               LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
configuration.serving.knative.dev/my-service                   my-service-01                 Unknown

NAME                                         URL                                                    LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
service.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://my-service.proxy-services-dev.example.com   my-service-01                 Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                             CONFIG NAME      K8S SERVICE NAME   GENERATION   READY     REASON      ACTUAL REPLICAS   DESIRED REPLICAS
revision.serving.knative.dev/my-service-01   my-service                      1            Unknown   Deploying   0                 1

NAME                                       URL                                                    READY     REASON
route.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://proxy-services.proxy-services-dev.example.com   Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                         ARN                                                                                                             AGE
virtualnode.appmesh.k8s.aws/my-service   arn:aws:appmesh:af-south-1:220716160778:mesh/proxy-services-dev/virtualNode/my-service_proxy-services-dev   11m
```


My manifests:


```
apiVersion: serving.knative.dev/v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      name: {{ .Chart.Name }}-01
      annotations:
        autoscaling.knative.dev/minScale: "1"
      labels:
        application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
    spec:
      serviceAccountName: {{ .Chart.Name }}
      containers:
        - name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
          image: "***"
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8443



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: Mesh
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  namespaceSelector:
    matchLabels:
      mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}



apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
  labels:
    mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}
    appmesh.k8s.aws/sidecarInjectorWebhook: enabled



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: VirtualNode
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  podSelector:
    matchLabels:
      application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
```


Ive tested the same knative service without App Mesh, then traffic routing works fine, it only breaks as soon as I use App Mesh sidecar injection.

This could be a great feature to add to knative. Reason:
We run an AWS EKS Fargate cluster. Fargate does not support istio CNI. Its not possible for us to use any service mesh's sidecard injection, on fargate, except for App Mesh. This is a known AWS Fargate limitation.

Using AWS App Mesh with Knative will thus be valuable, for anyone running AWS EKS Fargate clusters.

issue.title: Upgrade to 1.6.0 resulted in an error with Invalid value: "v1alpha1": must appear in spec.versions

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Upgrading the operator from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0 resulted in the following message 

```bash
Resource: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Resource=customresourcedefinitions", GroupVersionKind: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Kind=CustomResourceDefinition"
Name: "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev", Namespace: ""
for: "https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml": CustomResourceDefinition.apiextensions.k8s.io "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev" is invalid: status.storedVersions[0]: Invalid value: "v1alpha1": must appear in spec.versions

```

If I then check the CRD 
```bash
kubectl  get crd knativeservings.operator.knative.dev -o yaml | tail -n 20 

# I see v1alpha1 listed which is what I think it is complaining about
status:
  acceptedNames:
    kind: KnativeServing
    listKind: KnativeServingList
    plural: knativeservings
    singular: knativeserving
  conditions:
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: no conflicts found
    reason: NoConflicts
    status: "True"
    type: NamesAccepted
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: the initial names have been accepted
    reason: InitialNamesAccepted
    status: "True"
    type: Established
  storedVersions:
  - v1alpha1
  - v1beta1

```
**Expected behavior**
The operator to apply without error.

**To Reproduce**
Upgrade of knative serving.

```bash

# 1st upgrade from 0.24.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.25.0/operator.yaml
update version to 0.25.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 2nd upgrade from 0.25.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.26.3/operator.yaml
update version to 0.26.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 3 upgrade from 0.26.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.0.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.0.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 4 upgrade from 1.0.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.1.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.1.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

#5 upgrade from 1.1.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.2.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.2.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 6 upgrade from 1.2.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.3.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.3.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

ONCE CLUSTER IS AT 1.22 then we can do the following.
# 7 upgrade from 1.3.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.4.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.4.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 8 upgrade from 1.4.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.5.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.5.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace
change the apiversion to operator.knative.dev/v1beta1

At the next upgrade is when the error occurs

# 8 upgrade from 1.5.1
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml
update version to 1.6.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

```

**Knative release version**
started at 0.24

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here such as proposed priority

issue.title: Add go function invocation runtime as a package

labels.name: needs-rebase
labels.description: Indicates a PR cannot be merged because it has merge conflicts with HEAD.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: size/XXL
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: do-not-merge/hold
labels.description: Indicates that a PR should not merge because someone has issued a /hold command.

issue.body:
# Changes

This change takes the Golang function invocation framework from [boson-project/packs](https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/e8e1b3b08ac5599c71e999a52a0ff4c0432baa29/buildpacks/go/faas) and adds that code as a package to `func` itself. We should consider instead if it makes more sense to move this to https://github.com/knative/pkg.

- 🎁 Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- 🎁 Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package

## Motivation

Doing this will remove some of the "magic" from how a Golang function works. It also solves a number of problems.

- Eliminates the need to maintain a function-specific buildpack in https://github.com/boson-project/packs
- Allows us to default to the paketo golang buildpack alone, and for users to use any go-capable buildpack they want
- Enables on-cluster builds for Go functions, which is currently prevented by limitations in the Tekton task related to specifying additional buildpacks
- Enables s2i builds for Go functions, as the framework is now simply a library dependency instead of being applied in the buildpack
- Enables the function developer to run the function locally without requiring a container image and docker daemon
- Makes the function invocation mechanism for Go functions more transparent/open for greater potential community input

## Areas of concern

- Requires a minimal `main()` to be included in the Go function templates (this PR adds `faas/main.go`)
- Requires either `go.sum` in the Go function templates, or the user must generate it before an initial `func build` (this PR adds `go.sum`)
- Adds gorilla/mux as a dependency to `func` (unless the package is moved to `knative.dev/pkg/runtime`)

## TODO
- [x] Remove check preventing on-cluster builds for golang
- [ ] Update go.mod `replace` directives if/when this PR lands (is there a better way to do this?)
- [ ] Update template README.md docs to provide instructions on how to run the function locally

/kind enhancement

Fixes: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/809
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/984
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/pull/1445

## Release notes
```release-notes
- Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package
```

issue.title: Determine the process of how/what envoy configurations we support

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
There are some requests to add a new Envoy configuration on Kourier recently.
But we don't have the process of how/what envoy configurations we support and so the new configurations could mess up the Kourier code and cause confusion why this is supported but why this is not.
We should determine the process.

### How to support the configuration

In many cases, the configuration could be supported by introducing a new annotation.
However, the annotation solution is a double-edged sword, which means easy to add but mess up the configuration. (we will eventually support a ton of the annotations).
Is there any better way?

### What envoy feature/configuration support

There are so many envoy configurations. We probably need to select some of them with a criteria such as many users requested, critical configurations and so on.

issue.title: Integration with Argo Rollouts

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: area/API
labels.description: API objects and controllers

labels.name: kind/spec
labels.description: Discussion of how a feature should be exposed to customers.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
/area API
/area monitoring
/kind spec

## Ask your question here:

Hey folks! In my setup I'm using Argo Rollouts to rollout different applications. I combine it with ArgoCD as well to take full advantage of GitOps. I've been playing around with the Canary, Blue/Green deployment of the `Service` CRD of Knative Serving but I was wondering if there was a way to leverage Argo Rollouts instead of the default rollout mechanism. What I am trying to achieve is the automatic rollback of a `Revision` based on rules that I can set per individual `Service`. 
Maybe this could be a `feature-request` rather than a question, however, before moving on I'd like to know if there are already mechanisms to take advantage of Argo Rollouts.

labels.name: size/XS

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: Paul S. Schweigert <paul@paulschweigert.com>

Github recently made the `ubuntu-latest` runner label refer to Ubuntu 22.04 (before it had been 20.04). 22.04 uses cgroups v2 by default, whereas 20.04 was still using cgroups v1.

It seems that our cgroups conformance tests were written for cgroups v1, as they fail when using cgroups v2 (tested on both Ubuntu 22.04 and Fedora 36).

As a short-term solution, this patch will keep running the e2e tests on Ubuntu 20.04, until we have a chance to rewrite the conformance tests to work with cgroups v2.

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: Paul S. Schweigert <paul@paulschweigert.com>

Github recently made the `ubuntu-latest` runner label refer to Ubuntu 22.04 (before it had been 20.04). 22.04 uses cgroups v2 by default, whereas 20.04 was still using cgroups v1.

It seems that our cgroups conformance tests were written for cgroups v1, as they fail when using cgroups v2 (tested on both Ubuntu 22.04 and Fedora 36).

As a short-term solution, this patch will keep running the e2e tests on Ubuntu 20.04, until we have a chance to rewrite the conformance tests to work with cgroups v2.

issue.title: Allow more control on configuration of virtual services being created by net-istio controller.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
### Context:
We are running kserve on top of knative-serving. For every kserve InferenceService (aka ISVC), 3 virtual services are being created by net-istio controller:
1. one created with the same name as ISVC => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
2. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-ingress => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
3. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-mesh => bound to `mesh` gateway

Now, at our org, we have a central team that manages service mesh and they have a set of rules (implemented via validation webhooks) in place for every istio resource like VS, GW, Service Entry etc.
One such rule is, for every virtual service that is bound to a mesh gateway, it is mandatory to have `exportTo:"."` in that virtual service's spec.

### Ask:
It should be possible to influence the configurations of virtual services created by net-istio controller as every organization can have a central service mesh team having their own set of rules enforced.

issue.title: What does the concurrency really mean?

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue with Knative, send an email to knative-security@googlegroups.com. -->

In what area(s)?
> /area metrics

The question is about the metrics system.
Let's assume that:
- there is only one autoscaler and an activator which regularly (1s) reports its metrics to the autoscaler
- the response time is infinite, which means the request will never end (timeout config is also infinite)

In my opinion, the concurrency is just the "current" request numbers which the activator (and the pods behind it) is dealing with. That means, if there is one request comes at the first second, and another comes at the second second... and so on, then the concurrency is 1 at the first second and 2 at the second second... Is that right?

However in knative, the activator will reset its data after it reports its metrics periodically, which means it doesn't know the request it received at the last report frame, so it will report 1 AverageConcurrency at the 1st second, and another 1 AverageConcurrency at the 2nd... and so on. Thus the autoscaler will think the concurrency is always equal to one by the whole StableWindow (60s) . But actually all the requests are being processed by the backend, **so the question is **,  what is the right concurrency after the whole StableWindow, 60 or 1?

Thanks a lot.

issue.title: Knative + Kourier -  use with AWS App Mesh

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Well-understood/specified features, ready for coding.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
Hi there.

Problem statement: Use knative + Kourier with AWS App Mesh sidecar injection

Detail:

We know its possible to use Istio's Service Mesh (sidecar injection) with Knative.
I have also seen resources to do the same with Linkerd.

It would be great if we can get the same for AWS App Mesh.

Ive tried injecting the envoy sidecar with Knative + AppMesh. The sidecar injects and the pod starts up fine with 3/3 containers. 
Traffic/routing doesnt work as soon as the envoy sidecar is added.
I see that as soon as the envoy container is added, the k8s Service - External Name is not being created:

(you will see two services below instead of the 3 knative usually creates, also please note the "Unkowns" and "RevisionMissing")


```
NAME                                TYPE        CLUSTER-IP       EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)                                      AGE
service/my-service-01           ClusterIP   172.20.198.104   <none>        80/TCP                                       11m
service/my-service-01-private   ClusterIP   172.20.218.251   <none>        80/TCP,9090/TCP,9091/TCP,8022/TCP,8012/TCP   11m

NAME                                           READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
deployment.apps/my-service-01-deployment   0/1     1            0           11m

NAME                                                      DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/my-service-01-deployment-59d9bc7778   1         1         0       11m

NAME                                               LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
configuration.serving.knative.dev/my-service                   my-service-01                 Unknown

NAME                                         URL                                                    LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
service.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://my-service.proxy-services-dev.example.com   my-service-01                 Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                             CONFIG NAME      K8S SERVICE NAME   GENERATION   READY     REASON      ACTUAL REPLICAS   DESIRED REPLICAS
revision.serving.knative.dev/my-service-01   my-service                      1            Unknown   Deploying   0                 1

NAME                                       URL                                                    READY     REASON
route.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://proxy-services.proxy-services-dev.example.com   Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                         ARN                                                                                                             AGE
virtualnode.appmesh.k8s.aws/my-service   arn:aws:appmesh:af-south-1:220716160778:mesh/proxy-services-dev/virtualNode/my-service_proxy-services-dev   11m
```


My manifests:


```
apiVersion: serving.knative.dev/v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      name: {{ .Chart.Name }}-01
      annotations:
        autoscaling.knative.dev/minScale: "1"
      labels:
        application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
    spec:
      serviceAccountName: {{ .Chart.Name }}
      containers:
        - name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
          image: "***"
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8443



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: Mesh
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  namespaceSelector:
    matchLabels:
      mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}



apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
  labels:
    mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}
    appmesh.k8s.aws/sidecarInjectorWebhook: enabled



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: VirtualNode
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  podSelector:
    matchLabels:
      application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
```


Ive tested the same knative service without App Mesh, then traffic routing works fine, it only breaks as soon as I use App Mesh sidecar injection.

This could be a great feature to add to knative. Reason:
We run an AWS EKS Fargate cluster. Fargate does not support istio CNI. Its not possible for us to use any service mesh's sidecard injection, on fargate, except for App Mesh. This is a known AWS Fargate limitation.

Using AWS App Mesh with Knative will thus be valuable, for anyone running AWS EKS Fargate clusters.

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Upgrading the operator from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0 resulted in the following message 

```bash
Resource: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Resource=customresourcedefinitions", GroupVersionKind: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Kind=CustomResourceDefinition"
Name: "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev", Namespace: ""
for: "https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml": CustomResourceDefinition.apiextensions.k8s.io "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev" is invalid: status.storedVersions[0]: Invalid value: "v1alpha1": must appear in spec.versions

```

If I then check the CRD 
```bash
kubectl  get crd knativeservings.operator.knative.dev -o yaml | tail -n 20 

# I see v1alpha1 listed which is what I think it is complaining about
status:
  acceptedNames:
    kind: KnativeServing
    listKind: KnativeServingList
    plural: knativeservings
    singular: knativeserving
  conditions:
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: no conflicts found
    reason: NoConflicts
    status: "True"
    type: NamesAccepted
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: the initial names have been accepted
    reason: InitialNamesAccepted
    status: "True"
    type: Established
  storedVersions:
  - v1alpha1
  - v1beta1

```
**Expected behavior**
The operator to apply without error.

**To Reproduce**
Upgrade of knative serving.

```bash

# 1st upgrade from 0.24.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.25.0/operator.yaml
update version to 0.25.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 2nd upgrade from 0.25.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.26.3/operator.yaml
update version to 0.26.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 3 upgrade from 0.26.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.0.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.0.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 4 upgrade from 1.0.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.1.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.1.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

#5 upgrade from 1.1.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.2.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.2.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 6 upgrade from 1.2.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.3.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.3.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

ONCE CLUSTER IS AT 1.22 then we can do the following.
# 7 upgrade from 1.3.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.4.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.4.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 8 upgrade from 1.4.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.5.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.5.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace
change the apiversion to operator.knative.dev/v1beta1

At the next upgrade is when the error occurs

# 8 upgrade from 1.5.1
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml
update version to 1.6.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

```

**Knative release version**
started at 0.24

issue.title: Add go function invocation runtime as a package

labels.name: needs-rebase
labels.description: Indicates a PR cannot be merged because it has merge conflicts with HEAD.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: size/XXL
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: do-not-merge/hold
labels.description: Indicates that a PR should not merge because someone has issued a /hold command.

issue.body:
# Changes

This change takes the Golang function invocation framework from [boson-project/packs](https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/e8e1b3b08ac5599c71e999a52a0ff4c0432baa29/buildpacks/go/faas) and adds that code as a package to `func` itself. We should consider instead if it makes more sense to move this to https://github.com/knative/pkg.

- 🎁 Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- 🎁 Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package

## Motivation

Doing this will remove some of the "magic" from how a Golang function works. It also solves a number of problems.

- Eliminates the need to maintain a function-specific buildpack in https://github.com/boson-project/packs
- Allows us to default to the paketo golang buildpack alone, and for users to use any go-capable buildpack they want
- Enables on-cluster builds for Go functions, which is currently prevented by limitations in the Tekton task related to specifying additional buildpacks
- Enables s2i builds for Go functions, as the framework is now simply a library dependency instead of being applied in the buildpack
- Enables the function developer to run the function locally without requiring a container image and docker daemon
- Makes the function invocation mechanism for Go functions more transparent/open for greater potential community input

## Areas of concern

- Requires a minimal `main()` to be included in the Go function templates (this PR adds `faas/main.go`)
- Requires either `go.sum` in the Go function templates, or the user must generate it before an initial `func build` (this PR adds `go.sum`)
- Adds gorilla/mux as a dependency to `func` (unless the package is moved to `knative.dev/pkg/runtime`)

## TODO
- [x] Remove check preventing on-cluster builds for golang
- [ ] Update go.mod `replace` directives if/when this PR lands (is there a better way to do this?)
- [ ] Update template README.md docs to provide instructions on how to run the function locally

/kind enhancement

Fixes: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/809
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/issues/984
Related: https://github.com/knative/func/pull/1445

## Release notes
```release-notes
- Adds the Go function invocation framework from https://github.com/boson-project/packs/tree/main/buildpacks/go as a package at knative.dev/func/runtime
- Updates the Go function templates to use the knative.dev/func/runtime package
```

issue.title: Determine the process of how/what envoy configurations we support

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
There are some requests to add a new Envoy configuration on Kourier recently.
But we don't have the process of how/what envoy configurations we support and so the new configurations could mess up the Kourier code and cause confusion why this is supported but why this is not.
We should determine the process.

### How to support the configuration

In many cases, the configuration could be supported by introducing a new annotation.
However, the annotation solution is a double-edged sword, which means easy to add but mess up the configuration. (we will eventually support a ton of the annotations).
Is there any better way?

### What envoy feature/configuration support

There are so many envoy configurations. We probably need to select some of them with a criteria such as many users requested, critical configurations and so on.

issue.title: Integration with Argo Rollouts

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: area/API
labels.description: API objects and controllers

labels.name: kind/spec
labels.description: Discussion of how a feature should be exposed to customers.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
/area API
/area monitoring
/kind spec

## Ask your question here:

Hey folks! In my setup I'm using Argo Rollouts to rollout different applications. I combine it with ArgoCD as well to take full advantage of GitOps. I've been playing around with the Canary, Blue/Green deployment of the `Service` CRD of Knative Serving but I was wondering if there was a way to leverage Argo Rollouts instead of the default rollout mechanism. What I am trying to achieve is the automatic rollback of a `Revision` based on rules that I can set per individual `Service`. 
Maybe this could be a `feature-request` rather than a question, however, before moving on I'd like to know if there are already mechanisms to take advantage of Argo Rollouts.

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: Paul S. Schweigert <paul@paulschweigert.com>

Github recently made the `ubuntu-latest` runner label refer to Ubuntu 22.04 (before it had been 20.04). 22.04 uses cgroups v2 by default, whereas 20.04 was still using cgroups v1.

It seems that our cgroups conformance tests were written for cgroups v1, as they fail when using cgroups v2 (tested on both Ubuntu 22.04 and Fedora 36).

As a short-term solution, this patch will keep running the e2e tests on Ubuntu 20.04, until we have a chance to rewrite the conformance tests to work with cgroups v2.

issue.title: Allow more control on configuration of virtual services being created by net-istio controller.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
### Context:
We are running kserve on top of knative-serving. For every kserve InferenceService (aka ISVC), 3 virtual services are being created by net-istio controller:
1. one created with the same name as ISVC => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
2. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-ingress => bound to `knative-ingress-gateway` and `knative-local-gateway`
3. ISVC_NAME-predictor-default-mesh => bound to `mesh` gateway

Now, at our org, we have a central team that manages service mesh and they have a set of rules (implemented via validation webhooks) in place for every istio resource like VS, GW, Service Entry etc.
One such rule is, for every virtual service that is bound to a mesh gateway, it is mandatory to have `exportTo:"."` in that virtual service's spec.

### Ask:
It should be possible to influence the configurations of virtual services created by net-istio controller as every organization can have a central service mesh team having their own set of rules enforced.

issue.title: What does the concurrency really mean?

labels.name: kind/question
labels.description: Further information is requested

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue with Knative, send an email to knative-security@googlegroups.com. -->

In what area(s)?
> /area metrics

The question is about the metrics system.
Let's assume that:
- there is only one autoscaler and an activator which regularly (1s) reports its metrics to the autoscaler
- the response time is infinite, which means the request will never end (timeout config is also infinite)

In my opinion, the concurrency is just the "current" request numbers which the activator (and the pods behind it) is dealing with. That means, if there is one request comes at the first second, and another comes at the second second... and so on, then the concurrency is 1 at the first second and 2 at the second second... Is that right?

However in knative, the activator will reset its data after it reports its metrics periodically, which means it doesn't know the request it received at the last report frame, so it will report 1 AverageConcurrency at the 1st second, and another 1 AverageConcurrency at the 2nd... and so on. Thus the autoscaler will think the concurrency is always equal to one by the whole StableWindow (60s) . But actually all the requests are being processed by the backend, **so the question is **,  what is the right concurrency after the whole StableWindow, 60 or 1?

Thanks a lot.

issue.title: Knative + Kourier -  use with AWS App Mesh

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Well-understood/specified features, ready for coding.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
Hi there.

Problem statement: Use knative + Kourier with AWS App Mesh sidecar injection

Detail:

We know its possible to use Istio's Service Mesh (sidecar injection) with Knative.
I have also seen resources to do the same with Linkerd.

It would be great if we can get the same for AWS App Mesh.

Ive tried injecting the envoy sidecar with Knative + AppMesh. The sidecar injects and the pod starts up fine with 3/3 containers. 
Traffic/routing doesnt work as soon as the envoy sidecar is added.
I see that as soon as the envoy container is added, the k8s Service - External Name is not being created:

(you will see two services below instead of the 3 knative usually creates, also please note the "Unkowns" and "RevisionMissing")


```
NAME                                TYPE        CLUSTER-IP       EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)                                      AGE
service/my-service-01           ClusterIP   172.20.198.104   <none>        80/TCP                                       11m
service/my-service-01-private   ClusterIP   172.20.218.251   <none>        80/TCP,9090/TCP,9091/TCP,8022/TCP,8012/TCP   11m

NAME                                           READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
deployment.apps/my-service-01-deployment   0/1     1            0           11m

NAME                                                      DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/my-service-01-deployment-59d9bc7778   1         1         0       11m

NAME                                               LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
configuration.serving.knative.dev/my-service                   my-service-01                 Unknown

NAME                                         URL                                                    LATESTCREATED       LATESTREADY   READY     REASON
service.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://my-service.proxy-services-dev.example.com   my-service-01                 Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                             CONFIG NAME      K8S SERVICE NAME   GENERATION   READY     REASON      ACTUAL REPLICAS   DESIRED REPLICAS
revision.serving.knative.dev/my-service-01   my-service                      1            Unknown   Deploying   0                 1

NAME                                       URL                                                    READY     REASON
route.serving.knative.dev/proxy-services   http://proxy-services.proxy-services-dev.example.com   Unknown   RevisionMissing

NAME                                         ARN                                                                                                             AGE
virtualnode.appmesh.k8s.aws/my-service   arn:aws:appmesh:af-south-1:220716160778:mesh/proxy-services-dev/virtualNode/my-service_proxy-services-dev   11m
```


My manifests:


```
apiVersion: serving.knative.dev/v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      name: {{ .Chart.Name }}-01
      annotations:
        autoscaling.knative.dev/minScale: "1"
      labels:
        application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
    spec:
      serviceAccountName: {{ .Chart.Name }}
      containers:
        - name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
          image: "***"
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8443



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: Mesh
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  namespaceSelector:
    matchLabels:
      mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}



apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.namespace }}
  labels:
    mesh: {{ .Values.namespace }}
    appmesh.k8s.aws/sidecarInjectorWebhook: enabled



apiVersion: appmesh.k8s.aws/v1beta2
kind: VirtualNode
metadata:
  name: {{ .Chart.Name }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  podSelector:
    matchLabels:
      application: {{ .Chart.Name }}
```


Ive tested the same knative service without App Mesh, then traffic routing works fine, it only breaks as soon as I use App Mesh sidecar injection.

This could be a great feature to add to knative. Reason:
We run an AWS EKS Fargate cluster. Fargate does not support istio CNI. Its not possible for us to use any service mesh's sidecard injection, on fargate, except for App Mesh. This is a known AWS Fargate limitation.

Using AWS App Mesh with Knative will thus be valuable, for anyone running AWS EKS Fargate clusters.

Most PRs should be opened against the main branch in the
[`knative/docs` GitHub repository](https://github.com/knative/docs).

Use one of the content templates when writing a new document:
- [Concept](docs/contributor/templates/template-concept.md) -- Conceptual topics explain how things
work or what things mean. They provide helpful context to readers. They do not include procedures.
- [Procedure](docs/contributor/templates/template-procedure.md) -- Procedural (how-to) topics
include detailed steps for performing a task as well as some context about the task.
- [Troubleshooting](docs/contributor/templates/template-troubleshooting.md) -- Troubleshooting
topics list common errors and solutions.
- [Blog](docs/contributor/templates/template-blog-entry.md) -- Instructions and a template that you
can use to help you post to the Knative blog.

When you add a new document to the /docs directory, the navigation menu updates automatically.
For more information, see the
[MkDocs documentation](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/#configure-pages-and-navigation).

If your changes should also be in the most recent release, use [/cherrypick](https://prow.k8s.io/command-help#cherrypick) command;

For all resources for contributing to the Knative documentation, see the
[Knative contributor's guide](help/contributing/README.md).

 -->

issue.title: Upgrade to 1.6.0 resulted in an error with Invalid value: "v1alpha1": must appear in spec.versions

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Upgrading the operator from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0 resulted in the following message 

```bash
Resource: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Resource=customresourcedefinitions", GroupVersionKind: "apiextensions.k8s.io/v1, Kind=CustomResourceDefinition"
Name: "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev", Namespace: ""
for: "https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml": CustomResourceDefinition.apiextensions.k8s.io "knativeservings.operator.knative.dev" is invalid: status.storedVersions[0]: Invalid value: "v1alpha1": must appear in spec.versions

```

If I then check the CRD 
```bash
kubectl  get crd knativeservings.operator.knative.dev -o yaml | tail -n 20 

# I see v1alpha1 listed which is what I think it is complaining about
status:
  acceptedNames:
    kind: KnativeServing
    listKind: KnativeServingList
    plural: knativeservings
    singular: knativeserving
  conditions:
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: no conflicts found
    reason: NoConflicts
    status: "True"
    type: NamesAccepted
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-07-22T04:00:58Z"
    message: the initial names have been accepted
    reason: InitialNamesAccepted
    status: "True"
    type: Established
  storedVersions:
  - v1alpha1
  - v1beta1

```
**Expected behavior**
The operator to apply without error.

**To Reproduce**
Upgrade of knative serving.

```bash

# 1st upgrade from 0.24.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.25.0/operator.yaml
update version to 0.25.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 2nd upgrade from 0.25.0
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/v0.26.3/operator.yaml
update version to 0.26.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 3 upgrade from 0.26.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.0.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.0.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 4 upgrade from 1.0.0
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.1.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.1.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

#5 upgrade from 1.1.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.2.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.2.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 6 upgrade from 1.2.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.3.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.3.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

ONCE CLUSTER IS AT 1.22 then we can do the following.
# 7 upgrade from 1.3.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.4.2/operator.yaml
update version to 1.4.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

# 8 upgrade from 1.4.2
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.5.1/operator.yaml
update version to 1.5.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace
change the apiversion to operator.knative.dev/v1beta1

At the next upgrade is when the error occurs

# 8 upgrade from 1.5.1
k apply -f https://github.com/knative/operator/releases/download/knative-v1.6.0/operator.yaml
update version to 1.6.0 in knativeserving  resource  and apply 
watch the pods in the knative-serving namespace

```

**Knative release version**
started at 0.24

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here such as proposed priority

issue.title: Get rid of 2 skipped tests because of spec non-compliance

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
**Problem**
There are 2 tests copy&pasted from upstream knative/eventing :
- https://github.com/knative/eventing/blob/68d441013ca8c65c5b9a7f97d8f8be7e922d8a13/test/rekt/channel_test.go#L163
- https://github.com/knative/eventing/blob/68d441013ca8c65c5b9a7f97d8f8be7e922d8a13/test/rekt/channel_test.go#L211

These tests are actually testing something that's not compliant to the spec. 

This ticket is created to get rid of that non-compliance: https://github.com/knative/eventing/issues/5756

The tests could've been deleted already in this repo, but kept for awareness.

**[Persona:](https://github.com/knative/eventing/blob/master/docs/personas.md)** 
Which persona is this feature for?
